column1: text

Today‚Äôs strong headline job numbers mask weak momentum in the labor market. Nearly all of January‚Äôs payroll gains came from Healthcare and Social Assistance‚Äîthe same sector that generated essentially all job growth in 2025. Payrolls contracted three to four times last year, underscoring weak momentum. Despite weak momentum, the bottom hasn‚Äôt fallen out of the labor market. Unemployment edged down (largely because fewer people entered or reentered the labor force, not because hiring strengthened).  1. Payrolls January nonfarm payrolls increased by 130K, well above expectations. Healthcare and Social Assistance account for the vast majority of the gains with solid gains in Construction from commercial contractors. Average monthly payroll growth in 2025 was cut from 49K to 15K with annual revisions. The new payroll benchmark now anchors employment to March 2025. After March, the rest of 2025 saw much smaller downward revisions, ‚Äì90K per month versus ‚Äì14K. Thus, more downward revisions to the latter half of 2025 may still lie ahead. Current estimates indicate payrolls contracted over a third of months in 2025.  2. Unemployment Unemployment fell to 4.3%, coming in below expectations. The drop reflects fewer entrants and reentrants rather than job losses. Part‚Äëtime work for economic reasons remains near its highest level since spring 2021 but continues to normalize after spiking during the 2025 government shutdown. Household survey data show employment has grown by 57K per month since January 2025.  3. Labor Supply & Earnings For prime-age workers (25‚Äì54), labor force participation rose to its highest level since April 2000 from December to January, and the employment‚Äëto‚Äëpopulation ratio rose to its highest level since March 2001. This is the first meaningful acceleration in labor supply growth since mid-2024. Wage growth accelerated: average hourly earnings rose at a 5.0% annualized pace in January (4.6% for production and nonsupervisory workers), up from 0.7% (1.5%) in December. Despite this, wage‚Äëdriven inflation pressure remains unconcerning.  4. Potential Warning Signals Temp Agency employment rose by 9K, after hitting a trough in October. Unemployment rates for youth (ages 16‚Äì19) and Black workers declined but remained more than 15% above their levels at the start of 2025. Beyond the familiar skew in payroll growth, today‚Äôs report shows no red flags.  5. Technical Notes Today‚Äôs establishment survey data (i.e., payroll growth) reflect revisions to the count of total payment employment (benchmark), seasonal adjustment factors, and establishment birth-death model estimates. However, updates related to population controls in the household survey will be published in March and applied retroactively through January.

TL;DR: January's BLS jobs report was the 2nd good one in a row - arguably, not just a good report, but very good. Nevertheless, the job market is still in slightly worse shape than it was a year ago.  More:  1/ As always, "this is just one report". People overreacted with pessimism after a string of weak reports last fall; I would caution against overreacting with optimism this time around.  2/ December's jobs report was a very good one. The unemployment rate fell for the second consecutive month, to 4.28% (the lowest since July 2025). Nonfarm payroll employment increased by 130K, the most since December 2024.  3/ The share of prime-working-age Americans with a job rose to 80.9%, the highest since the summer of 2024.  4/ The prime-working-age labor force participation rate rose to 84.1%, the highest since 2021.  5/ The share of people working part time for economic reasons fell to 2.84% of the labor force - the lowest since the fall. This had been one of the weakest aspects of recent reports.  6/ The unemployment rate for 20-24 year olds fell to 7.1%, its lowest level since 2024. The unemployment rate for 18-19 year olds fell to 12.1%, its lowest level since September 2025.  7/ All the data above is from the BLS's household survey lot of attention is being paid to revisions to the establishment survey (both surveys provide data to the monthly employment report). The benchmark revision (to March 2025 employment levels) was -898K (so about -75K per month for the period from March 2024 to March 2025) and nonfarm payroll employment levels in December 2025 were about 1 million lower than previously believed. But: given what we know from data like the unemployment rate, this shouldn't change your opinion on the state of the labor market.  7/ The industries with the biggest job gains in January: health care & social assistance (+124K), construction (+33K), professional and business services ex temp agencies (+25K)  8/ The industries with the biggest employment declines in January: federal government (-34K), state government (-18K), transportation & warehousing (-11K)

The January 2026 jobs report just confirmed what 125 years of labor data already told us.  Healthcare added 82,000 jobs. Construction added 33,000. Social assistance added 42,000.  Federal government lost 34,000. Financial activities lost 22,000. +157,000 jobs in healthcare and trades. -56,000 in white collar. In one month.  I've been tracking U.S. employment by sector going back to 1900. Agriculture peaked at 40%, then collapsed. Service peaked at 26%. Trades peaked at 26%. Every dominant sector hits a ceiling and falls.  White collar is at 66% of the workforce right now. And for the first time, a jobs report showed zero white collar growth while healthcare and trades carried the entire month.  This is the peak.  AI is doing to knowledge work what the tractor did to the field. I've watched it play out inside my own businesses for three years. Work that used to require five people now requires one person who knows how to use the tools. But here's what nobody is talking about: the people holding skilled trade and manufacturing jobs right now are boomers. 64 million of them, ages 61 to 79, shrinking every year. Millennials and Gen Z, 74 million and 71 million respectively, overwhelmingly chose college and white collar paths. For every tradesperson retiring, only 0.6 new workers enter the field.  499,000 construction workers needed this year. 550,000 plumber shortage by 2027. Nearly a third of union electricians near retirement. And these jobs pay $80K to $105K+.  Healthcare has grown every single decade for 125 years. It's the only line on the chart that has never gone down. 20 million Americans work in healthcare today and the sector needs 22 million by 2030.  You have three options right now:  Skill up on AI. Make yourself the person your company cannot afford to lose. You have 6 to 12 months.  Reskill into trades or healthcare. Same 6 to 12 month timeline. Real demand. Real pay.  Do both. The tradesperson who understands AI and automation is going to be the most valuable worker in America in five years. The nurse who can use AI diagnostic tools is going to run circles around the one who can't. Sitting there waiting is not an option.

Are we past the bottom of the labor market slowdown? January saw strong job growth after a dismal 2025.  Payroll jobs rose by 130,000 in January and the unemployment rate ticked down another tenth of a percent to 4.3%.   January job growth was nearly equal to the total job growth of 181,000 experienced in ALL of 2025. With the release of annual benchmark data revisions for the April 2024 to March 2025 period, job growth in 2025 averaged just 15,000 per month.  Job growth continues to be centered in a limited number of sectors, especially health care, which added 82,000 jobs in January. Over the past twelve months, the healthcare job base has risen by 473,000, more than total job growth over this period. The only other sectors to add a significant number of jobs in January were construction (up 33,000) and professional and business services (up 34,000).   Federal government jobs fell by 34,000 in January and are down 324,000 from their January 2025 level.   Overall job growth in January was the most rapid since December 2024. With rising employment from the household survey also nudging the unemployment rate down for the second month in a row, this raises the tantalizing possibility that we have seen the worst of this downward labor market cycle. But the continuing concentration of job growth in just one sector means we continue to wait for signs of a broad-based labor market improvement.

For the month of January, the job market ended up looking better than expected. But that's also a function of how lackluster it was in 2025, particularly with revisions, which resulted in average monthly job creation of just 15,000 for the entire year. In addition, payroll gains are largely confined to health care and social assistance.   There are reasons to be upbeat about 2026, including the benefits of tax law changes, a lower federal funds rate (courtesy of the Federal Reserve) and that the economy has been adjusting to tariffs.   What is your view of the status of the job market, and perhaps even how it affects your career or personal finances? Please share in the comments section.   Here's my take on the latest data released by the Labor Department.

Make that a new record YoY losing streak for Professional and Business Services jobs. As I've previously noted, this is the first time going back to the series start in the 1940s that we see this kind of white collar contraction without overlapping an official recession (as far as we know, since recession declarations are typically lagged).  The +130,000 payroll jobs reported by BLS this morning masks a narrow and fragile base for job gains. Two primary sources of January payroll growth were Healthcare (historically acyclical) and Construction (but really nonresidential construction, likely data centers and perhaps some infrastructure repair after December natural disasters).

Make that a new record YoY losing streak for Professional and Business Services jobs. As I've previously noted, this is the first time going back to the series start in the 1940s that we see this kind of white collar contraction without overlapping an official recession (as far as we know, since recession declarations are typically lagged).  The +130,000 payroll jobs reported by BLS this morning masks a narrow and fragile base for job gains. Two primary sources of January payroll growth were Healthcare (historically acyclical) and Construction (but really nonresidential construction, likely data centers and perhaps some infrastructure repair after December natural disasters).

The US labor market continues to suprise, with the January jobs report coming in much stronger than expected.   The monthly jobs report, which was delayed again because of another federal government shutdown, showed that job growth in America accelerated in January. Employers added 130,000 jobs in January, compared to 48,000 jobs added the previous month. This was nearly double the number of jobs expected by analysts heading into the report.  The unemployment rate dropped to 4.3% in January, down from 4.4% the previous month. And labor force participation increased to 62.5%, up from 62.4% the previous month. This means that we're pulling more people off the sidelines and getting them more engaged in the labor market  Wage growth was mixed in January. On a month-over-month basis, wages grew 0.4%, up from 0.1% the previous month. On a year-over-year basis, wage growth slowed slightly to 3.7%, down from 3.8% the previous month. But this is still above inflation, which is a good sign that real wages are increasing.  We continue to see job gains in healthcare, social assistance, and construction, while federal government and financial activities lost jobs last month.  The only outstanding negative from the report was the annual benchmark revisions, which showed much lower estimates for job growth in 2025 The new estimates show that the U.S. economy added just 181,000 jobs in 2025, down from the earlier estimate of 584,000 jobs. However, this was not unexpected so it was largely priced-in by markets.  This report shows that once again, calls of the deterioration of the U.S. labor market are premature. This is good news for the economy and for markets; however it feeds the argument that the Federal Reserve should hold back on further interest rates cuts going forward into 2026.

Today‚Äôs jobs report with 130,000 jobs added‚Äì is another reminder that the U.S. labor market can be both resilient and uneven at the same time.  On the surface, the headline number will be labeled ‚Äúgood‚Äù or ‚Äúbad‚Äù by the market in a matter of minutes. But if you talk to business owners, workers and families, you hear a more complex story:  ¬∑ Many people who want a job, still have one, and businesses are finding ways to adapt with productivity and technology.  ¬∑ At the same time, affordability remains a real challenge ‚Äì housing, food, healthcare, education and everyday services are taking a bigger share of many household budgets than they did a decade or two ago.  ¬∑ The gap between the various segments of the economy is widening in certain parts of the country, even as national data looks solid.  From my seat as a regional bank CEO, I try to separate noise from signal:  ¬∑ Signal is the trend in employment, wages, business formation and credit quality over time ‚Äì not just one print.  ¬∑ Signal is what our clients are telling us about orders, pipelines, hiring plans and investment decisions in their local markets.  ¬∑ Noise is the daily swirl of headlines and political soundbites that don‚Äôt translate into actual policy or behavior.  Whatever today‚Äôs number is, there are a few practical questions I encourage business owners and leaders to ask themselves:  1. What are my own data points telling me? ‚Äì Revenue trends, open roles, turnover, late payments, local demand.  2. Where are my employees feeling the most pressure?  ‚Äì Wage expectations, commute and housing costs, childcare, healthcare. If your team is struggling with affordability, that will show up in retention and productivity over time.  3. Am I positioned for a ‚Äúnormalized‚Äù economy rather than the extremes of the last few years? ‚Äì Sensible leverage, conservative underwriting, thoughtful use of technology and a focus on core clients are more important than trying to time the next Fed move.  I remain optimistic about the U.S. economy in 2026. We‚Äôre still the most innovative, dynamic market in the world, but I‚Äôm equally clear-eyed that pockets of real pain exist and can‚Äôt be ignored. Both can be true at once: a strong overall engine with meaningful stress for certain households and sectors.  Leaders have to manage both realities: investing for growth where the data supports it, while staying very close to the people and communities who are feeling the squeeze. That‚Äôs where the real work and opportunity is right now.

Jobs Surge in January, but Massive Revisions Reveal a Much Weaker 2025  The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics released the January Employment Situation report this morning, and the headline numbers came in stronger than expected.  Nonfarm payrolls rose by 130,000, roughly double the consensus forecast of about 55,000 to 65,000 jobs.   The unemployment rate edged down to 4.3 percent instead of holding at 4.4 percent as expected. The labor force participation rate increased to 62.5 percent, and average hourly earnings rose 0.4 percent in the month and 3.7 percent over the year. Average weekly hours also moved higher, and manufacturing payrolls returned to positive territory.  Taken together, the January data point to a labor market that is still generating income and supporting consumer spending. Hiring beat expectations, unemployment declined, and both wages and hours worked moved in a direction consistent with stable household cash flow.  But the revisions tell a very different story about the past year.  The annual benchmark revision reduced payroll employment for March 2025 by roughly 860,000 jobs. More importantly, average monthly job growth for 2025 was revised down to about 15,000 per month, compared with roughly 49,000 previously estimated.  That changes the narrative around the labor market.  Instead of an economy that was steadily adding jobs through 2025 and is only now cooling, the revised data suggest job growth had already slowed to a near-stall pace last year. The labor market was not running hot and then suddenly weakening. It was already operating at a much lower speed than earlier estimates suggested.  That distinction matters for policy. A single strong payroll report does not erase a year of very modest job growth. For the Federal Reserve, the focus now shifts to whether unemployment begins to rise, not whether one monthly number beats expectations. If the labor market has been growing at only a minimal pace, it has less margin for error than previously believed.  For consumers, this type of environment usually means stability without acceleration. Employment remains solid, but job switching slows, wage gains become more measured, and spending behavior tends to shift toward essentials and high-confidence purchases.  The January report shows strength in the present. The revisions suggest weakness in the recent past. And it is that revised trend, not the single monthly surprise, that will ultimately shape policy decisions and consumer behavior.  Havas Edge tracks the labor market closely because shifts in hiring momentum often signal changes in consumer confidence and spending patterns before they appear in broader economic data.

The labor market just complicated the narrative.  January nonfarm payrolls rose 130,000, double the 65,000 economists expected. The unemployment rate ticked down to 4.3%, while average hourly earnings increased 0.4% month over month, keeping annual wage growth at 3.7%.  Within minutes, the 10-year Treasury yield rocketed 6 basis points higher.  This seems to be a clean upside surprise. Hiring continues and wage pressure is stable but not accelerating.  December payrolls were revised lower, though, as revisions for the prior two months were negative. The survey range going into the release was unusually wide as expectations were already subdued.  So what does this report signal?  It reduces the urgency of near-term Fed easing. A labor market that continues to generate jobs above expectations makes it harder to justify aggressive cuts. That is why bonds sold off immediately.  The move matters, particularly in the real estate industry. Six basis points on the 10-year in minutes changes permanent loan proceeds. Execution just shifted quickly.  Looking forward, the broader trend remains ambiguous. The market is left with a familiar tension: Is this stabilization, or a pause before slower data ahead?  For now, the signal is mixed and mixed signals tend to mean volatility.

Today‚Äôs jobs report is out and the US annual benchmark revision is the real star of the show. With these revisions, we‚Äôre seeing 2025 as the weakest year for US job growth (outside of the pandemic) in a very long time. Yet with a really good unemployment rate, the economy is telling us the situation is good‚Äînot great necessarily‚Äîbut good!  This has been and will continue to be such a weird business cycle. Can you have economic expansion without job growth? What does that mean for the US labor force experience?   None of this is in your macroeconomics textbook‚Äîbuckle up!

About 125 million people in the US watched the Super Bowl on Sunday night, making it the most-watched program in NBC‚Äôs 100-year history, the network said.  NBC, citing Nielsen ratings data, said the game ranked as ‚Äúthe second-most watched show in US history,‚Äù behind only last year‚Äôs Super Bowl, which was televised by Fox.  The official 124.9 million viewer figure is the average per-minute audience for all four quarters of the game.  The heavily scrutinized halftime performance by Bad Bunny registered an even larger audience: 128.2 million viewers.

Super Bowl ratings are officially out and I have thoughts.  None about who was playing, obviously.  Every year I‚Äôm more invested in the ads than the game. Grubhub & Claude were my faves. "Eat the fees" is living rent free in my head and Claude showed Pepsi how to actually build your brand while cleverly negging your competitor.  You might wince at the fact a 30-second spot reportedly cost 10 million bucks. But with official game ratings landing at 124.9M viewers across NBC, Peacock, Telemundo, NBC Sports Digital and NFL+, on a CPM basis that works out to a very reasonable $80. That's actually cheaper than most, if not all, Aussie sporting Grand Finals.  What fascinates me most is how this all became the thing. Throughout the 70s and 80s, advertisers realised that with this scale, influence and cultural relevance, you could do more than sell your product or service, you could entertain and become part of the cultural zeitgeist. Genius.  It makes me wonder why we don‚Äôt see this approach to advertising embedded into other big sporting or cultural moments.  Or how long Claude and Grubhub will survive on ad/fee-free models‚Ä¶.

Tough article for American Airlines today, but an important one. When frontline crews are sleeping on airport floors and both flight attendants and pilots issue no‚Äëconfidence votes, it signals more than a bad week‚Äîit points to deeper operational, cultural, and strategic gaps that have been building over time.  As someone who works closely with large, complex travel programs, I‚Äôm reminded that performance issues rarely stem from a single failure. They emerge when communication breaks down, when decision‚Äëmaking drifts too far from the realities of day‚Äëto‚Äëday operations, and when employees stop feeling supported.  American has the scale and talent to course‚Äëcorrect, but trust and stability have to be rebuilt from the inside out.

28,000 American Airlines flight attendants just voted no confidence in their CEO.  First time in the union's history. And the numbers are brutal:  - Q4 profit: $111M. Delta made $1.2B. United made $1B. - Dead last in J.D. Power customer satisfaction - WSJ ranked them last overall among US airlines - During a winter storm, crew slept on airport floors  Everyone's framing this as a leadership crisis. But look at the actual complaints:  1. Scheduling chaos during weather disruptions 2. No real-time crew reallocation 3. Slow customer rebooking during cancellations 4. Reactive operations instead of predictive  Every single one is a solvable operations problem.  AI agents today can handle real-time crew scheduling during disruptions. Predictive weather rerouting before storms hit. Automated customer rebooking in minutes, not hours.  I build AI agents for a different domain. But the principle is the same - the boring operational stuff is exactly what AI is best at. Not flashy demos. Real-time decision-making at scale.  American Airlines doesn't just have a leadership problem. It has a 2026 problem being solved with 1996 tools.  Source: CBS News

Ford Reports Biggest Profit Miss in Four Years  Ford Motor Co. (F) has reported mixed financial results for the fourth-quarter of 2025, including the company‚Äôs biggest profit miss in four years.  The Detroit automaker announced earnings per share (EPS) of $0.13, which was below the $0.19 expected among analysts.   The earnings per share came in 32% below consensus forecasts and was the company‚Äôs worst miss on profit since a 42% difference recorded in the fourth-quarter of 2021.  Ford‚Äôs revenue in the latest quarter totaled $42.4 billion, which was ahead of the $41.83 billion expected on Wall Street.   The company‚Äôs revenue for all of 2025 was a record $187.3 billion, up a slight 1% from $185 billion achieved a year earlier.

Google is offering voluntary exit packages to certain teams, as announced by CBO Philipp Schindler, emphasizing alignment with AI impact and strategy. I found it interesting that such proactive measures could reshape team dynamics and encourage a culture of commitment. What do you think about companies taking this approach to ensure alignment with their strategic goals?

Amazon's pharmacy business will expand its same-day delivery prescription service to about 4,500 cities and towns in the U.S. by the end of this year, adding nearly 2,000 new communities to the network.

The lesson Saks Fifth Avenue missed from Best Buy is the one Geoffroy van Raemdonck can still use.  When Hubert Joly took over Best Buy, the stores were treated as the liability.   Too many, too big, too expensive, and the customer was already moving online, often using stores to test and then buying elsewhere.  He flipped the premise.  The store was not the problem. The footprint was the underused assets.  Best Buy stopped treating square footage as storage and started treating it as a trust engine. Advice. Service. Installation. Repair. Education. The store became the moment of conviction, not the end of the funnel.  And the real lever was people.  Joly optimized retail by investing in the workforce. He raised frontline capability and made it the strategy. Expertise on the floor. Authority in the moment. Standards that held. Tech that amplified humans instead of replacing them. He rebuilt Best Buy around trust and advice, not just transactions and showrooming.  Saks Global is now in Chapter 11, and van Raemdonck is stepping into the role inside a hard reset. The instinct in this moment is to cut, shrink, and defend.  Best Buy‚Äôs turnaround says something cleaner.  When consumers have more choice, access stops being the value. Clarity becomes the value.  A flagship becomes an albatross when it is decorative. It becomes an opportunity when the people inside it are empowered to do real work.  Good leadership takes the greatest liability and recognizes it as its greatest asset.  A lesson I think of often.

Rewatched the Vogue Business Luxury Lowdown on the Saks restructuring, and it left me thinking about the true state of American retail.  There is a tension right now between retail health and asset structuring. As we look at the Saks Chapter 11 filing, we have to ask a difficult question: Is the department store model actually being saved, or is it simply being engineered into something else entirely?  Studying Risk Assessment at Questrom School of Business, Boston University, I see this as a textbook case of structural risk. It is a moment where the "point of failure" isn't just a lack of sales, but the weight of a capital structure that was built on assumptions that no longer hold true in today‚Äôs luxury market.  One of the most striking points from the discussion was the idea that survival today might not come from strengthening the store experience, but from how a company manages its real estate and high net worth consumption. When a legendary name like Saks moves through this kind of reckoning, it highlights a wider shift in the US ecosystem.  For those of us who value the story and the heritage of these spaces, it is a sobering look at a model in transition. If the future of luxury is less about the "shop" and more about the "structure," what does that mean for the human connection that once defined the industry?  Maliha Shoaib and Hilary Milnes did an incredible job unpacking these layers. I highly recommend catching the replay to see where the industry is headed in 2026.

It's only February, but 2026 is looking like another really bad year for retail and dining. Over 1000 closures have recently been announced, including Wendy‚Äôs, Macy‚Äôs, Pizza Hut, Carter‚Äôs, Kroger, and Yankee Candle. Eddie Bauer is looking at its third Chapter 11 and will sell off as many of its stores as it can and may shutter the rest. Even favorite REI is looking at closing at least three stores in the Northeast. The full extent of the bankruptcy of Saks Global (parent of Neiman Marcus) is yet to be announced. Every day, there seems to be a new announcement by a retailer or restaurant that is going through bankruptcy, downsizing, or shutting down for good. And that's not even including the tens of thousands of layoffs announced by Amazon and UPS.  The reason given for these closures is often that the stores, restaurants, or chains are underperforming. Some may not be able to compete with online alternatives. Others cite the rising costs of labor, materials and inventory, inflation and tariffs.  That the retail mix changes is really nothing new. Stores and restaurants have come and gone for decades. Sometimes it may be due to changes in consumer tastes, or it may be that a particular market has become over-saturated and can no longer support certain uses. And when retail and restaurant spaces go vacant, they are sometimes "absorbed" by more successful competitors looking to expand into new markets. But that's not always a guarantee.  So, why is someone who works as an urban designer and master planner concerned about retail and dining?  These uses are not only important components in a local and regional economy, but they are also vital elements in planning a mixed-use development. It is becoming more important that these developments be designed with the understanding that there will be a certain amount of "churn" over time. Flexibility is key. So too are the consideration of new uses not previously typically included.  That also applies to downtowns, which are dealing with the dual challenge of the changing retail environment and an office market that - in some cities - has not fully recovered from the pandemic.  Ideally, cities and developers could work together to find solutions that match their unique challenges. That may involve something as simple as eliminating parking minimums or streamlining approval processes for desired developments.  These challenges didn't happen overnight. Long-term solutions will take time.

I recently had the opportunity to visit our Saks Fifth Avenue Flagship in New York City alongside Darcy Penick ‚Äì my first time in the store since stepping into the role of CEO at Saks Global. I‚Äôve long admired the Saks Fifth Avenue brand for its heritage, influence on fashion and unwavering commitment to delivering a personalized customer experience. The visit underscored the foundational role the Flagship plays in our company‚Äôs history and our future. Most impactful was the time spent with our store associates and leaders, whose individual talents and deep commitment bring our brand to life and enable us to deliver exceptional experiences for our customers every day.  We discussed the progress we‚Äôve made in accessing additional liquidity and new inventory flow as well as how this moment is about making decisions that set the company up for profitable and sustainable growth at the service of our customers, brand partners and colleagues. I left the visit energized about what we can accomplish together, and deeply appreciative of the teams who bring our brands to life every day across our integrated retail model.  Thank you to the team for such a warm welcome. I look forward to more opportunities to connect with our colleagues over the coming months.

Capital markets answered  Alphabet just upsized its bond sale again, now pushing past $30B after demand kept building.  This started as a $20B raise. It got bigger because buyers kept showing up.  Why that matters  Equity investors flinched at the $185B AI capex number. Credit investors did the opposite. They leaned in.  That tells you something important. The market is not rejecting the AI spend. It is repricing how it wants to fund it.  Bond buyers care less about near term free cash flow dips and more about durability, scale, and balance sheet control. Alphabet checks those boxes, even with capex doubling.  This is becoming a pattern.  Oracle went first.  Alphabet followed and upsized.  Meta is lining one up next.  When multiple mega caps tap debt markets at this scale, it is not panic funding. It is a coordinated shift in how the AI buildout is financed.  If this were an AI bubble about to pop, credit would be the first place you would see stress.  Instead, demand keeps forcing deal sizes higher.

$32 billion in debt. In 24 hours. That's what Google just borrowed to fund AI infrastructure.  Oracle raised $25 billion last week. Morgan Stanley expects hyperscalers to borrow $400 billion this year.  When asked on the earnings call what worries him most, Google's CEO didn't hesitate: "compute capacity." Not model quality. Not competition.  "Power, land, supply chain constraints, how do you ramp up to meet this extraordinary demand."  That's the AI race happening right now, a race to infrastructure.  On the other hand, and that‚Äôs the part nobody wants to hear: Google is openly warning about "excess capacity" from their commitments in SEC filings.  They're borrowing $32 billion while simultaneously warning they might be building faster than they can use it.  So hyperscalers need to build the infra in order to deliver for AI demand, which itself depends on companies adopting AI before they have their own infrastructures in place.  Companies are making the same mistake in reverse.  They're deploying AI agents without solving infrastructure first. No rich context across systems. No reliable data sync. No integration that scales.  Our AI agents are only as smart as the infrastructure feeding them context.  That context lives in 47 different systems that don't talk to each other.  The companies adopting AI at scale aren't the ones with the fanciest models. They're the ones who solved integration before they scaled AI.   And hyperscalers need that to happen for AI demand to continue growing and justify those hundreds of billions in investment.

Kraft Heinz Pauses Breakup Plan, Stock Drops After Earnings  Kraft Heinz (KHC) shares fell 7.11% in pre-market trading Wednesday after the company announced it will pause plans to split into two businesses.  CEO Steve Cahillane said the opportunity ahead is larger than initially expected and that many of the company‚Äôs challenges are fixable and within its control.  His top priority is returning the business to profitable growth, with a focus on disciplined execution and fully aligned resources. The company also stated it does not expect to incur any dis-synergies in 2026.  Instead of pursuing a split, Kraft Heinz will invest $600 million into marketing, sales, and R&D. Management believes disciplined spending will allow the company to invest in its brands while continuing to generate excess cash.  The update came alongside earnings results. Adjusted EPS came in at 67 cents, beating Wall Street‚Äôs 61-cent estimate but declining 20% year over year. Revenue of $6.35 billion missed expectations of $6.37 billion and fell 3.4% year over year.  KHC shares are up 2.68% year to date but remain down 13% over the past 12 months.  Analysts currently rate the stock a consensus Hold, with an average price target of $24.44, implying modest downside from current levels.

Imagine building a ◊î◊ê◊©◊ò◊í#brand so strong that people recognize it without reading the ◊î◊ê◊©◊ò◊í#logo. A 100 year bond is not an ‚ÄúAI confidence‚Äù badge. It is a cash flow durability badge.  That is why it works for hyperscalers and is a very different ask for neocloud GPUaaS players.  Neoclouds can issue debt, but ‚Äúcentury bond‚Äù terms require three things most of them cannot prove yet: 1) diversified, recurring cash flows across cycles 2) low customer concentration 3) a balance sheet that can survive a pricing war and still cover fixed coupons  And your last line answers it. If issuing long dated debt would force higher prices for SMB customers, that means the business is still cost of capital sensitive. That profile does not get rewarded with ultra long duration paper at comfortable pricing.  So the signal stays the same: Credit is willing to fund the AI buildout when the issuer already has durable cash generation and distribution. For everyone else, funding exists, but it will be tighter, shorter, and more expensive until they earn that durability.

By issuing long term bonds instead of issuing a large number of new shares the company locks in low cost capital while avoiding equity dilution which also shows that management is very confident in the AI ‚Äã‚Äãpayback period they are willing to take on huge capital expenditures now in exchange for future computing power and data moat.

Capital markets answered  Alphabet just upsized its bond sale again, now pushing past $30B after demand kept building.  This started as a $20B raise. It got bigger because buyers kept showing up.  Why that matters  Equity investors flinched at the $185B AI capex number. Credit investors did the opposite. They leaned in.  That tells you something important. The market is not rejecting the AI spend. It is repricing how it wants to fund it.  Bond buyers care less about near term free cash flow dips and more about durability, scale, and balance sheet control. Alphabet checks those boxes, even with capex doubling.  This is becoming a pattern.  Oracle went first.  Alphabet followed and upsized.  Meta is lining one up next.  When multiple mega caps tap debt markets at this scale, it is not panic funding. It is a coordinated shift in how the AI buildout is financed.  If this were an AI bubble about to pop, credit would be the first place you would see stress.  Instead, demand keeps forcing deal sizes higher.

Agree. What stands out is not just demand for these deals, but what it implies about capital structure evolution. We may be moving toward a model where hyperscalers systematically arbitrage their balance sheets to fund AI buildouts, while equity absorbs the volatility. That‚Äôs a meaningful shift for long-term allocators.
